rev.diff:
Line 51: Line 51:
Texas Tech grew slowly in the early years. Military training was conducted at the college as early as 1925, but formal [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps]] training did not commence until 1936. By 1939, the school's enrollment had grown to 3,890. Though enrollment declined during [[World War II]], Texas Tech trained 4,747 men in its [[armed forces]] training detachments.<ref name=Handbook /> Following the war, in 1946, the college saw its enrollment leap to 5,366 from a low of 1,696 in 1943.<ref>{{cite web|title=Raw Enrollment Data|publisher=Texas Tech University|url=http://www.irs.ttu.edu/ARCHIVE/ENR/FALLENRL.HTM|accessdate=2008-08-22}}</ref>
Texas Tech grew slowly in the early years. Military training was conducted at the college as early as 1925, but formal [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps]] training did not commence until 1936. By 1939, the school's enrollment had grown to 3,890. Though enrollment declined during [[World War II]], Texas Tech trained 4,747 men in its [[armed forces]] training detachments.<ref name=Handbook /> Following the war, in 1946, the college saw its enrollment leap to 5,366 from a low of 1,696 in 1943.<ref>{{cite web|title=Raw Enrollment Data|publisher=Texas Tech University|url=http://www.irs.ttu.edu/ARCHIVE/ENR/FALLENRL.HTM|accessdate=2008-08-22}}</ref>
â
=== Expansion and growth of the best college ever ===
+
=== Expansion and growth ===
[[File:TTUadmin.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Administration Building (Texas Tech University)|Administration Building]]]]
[[File:TTUadmin.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Administration Building (Texas Tech University)|Administration Building]]]]
By the 1960s, the school had expanded its offerings to more than just technical subjects.<ref name=Controversy>{{cite web|last=Clark|first=Robert|title=The Name Change Controversy|publisher=Southwest Collection|date=January - February 1990|url=http://www.swco.ttu.edu/University_Archive/pdf/1990.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2008-07-31}}</ref> The Faculty Advisory Committee suggested changing the name to "Texas State University", feeling the phrase "Technological College" was insufficient to define the scope of the institution.<ref name=Fighting>{{cite news|last=Siegrist|first=Nikki|title=Tech Traditions: Fighting for Change|work=[[The Daily Toreador]]|date=2003-03-03|url=http://media.www.dailytoreador.com/media/storage/paper870/news/2003/03/03/CampusNews/Tech-Traditionsfighting.For.Change-1276134.shtml|accessdate=2008-08-09}}</ref> While most students supported this change, the Board of Directors and many alumni, wanting to preserve the [[Double T]], opposed it.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us: History|publisher=Texas Tech Alumni Association|url=http://www.texastechalumni.org/olc/pub/TTAA/cpages/about_us/history.jsp|accessdate=2008-08-10}}</ref> Other namesâUniversity of the Southwest, Texas Technological College and State University,<ref>{{cite news|last=Hensley|first=Doug|title=Triumph, tragedy in world's spotlight|work=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]|url=http://www.lubbockcentennial.com/Section/1959_1983/3_Hensley.shtml|accessdate=2008-08-10}}</ref> and The Texas University of Art, Science and Technologyâwere considered,<ref name=Game>{{cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20020123163409/redraiders.com/techs75th/namechange.htm|title=Tech began playing name-change game in '50s|accessdate=2008-08-10|work=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]|author=Elizabeth Langton}}</ref> but the Board of Directors chose Texas Tech University, submitting it to the state legislature in 1964. A failed move by [[John Connally|Governor John Connally]] to have the school placed into the [[Texas A&M University System]], as well as continued disagreement and heated debate regarding the school's new name, kept the name change from being approved.<ref name=Controversy /><ref name=Fighting /> In spite of objections by many students and faculty, the Board of Directors again submitted the change in 1969. It finally received the legislature's approval on June 6 and the name Texas Tech University went into effect that September.<ref name=Game /> All of the institution's schools, except Law, became colleges.<ref name=Handbook /><ref>{{cite web|title=General Information|publisher=Texas Tech University Office of Official Publications|url=http://www.depts.ttu.edu/officialpublications/facultyHB/general.php|accessdate=2008-08-12}}</ref>
By the 1960s, the school had expanded its offerings to more than just technical subjects.<ref name=Controversy>{{cite web|last=Clark|first=Robert|title=The Name Change Controversy|publisher=Southwest Collection|date=January - February 1990|url=http://www.swco.ttu.edu/University_Archive/pdf/1990.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2008-07-31}}</ref> The Faculty Advisory Committee suggested changing the name to "Texas State University", feeling the phrase "Technological College" was insufficient to define the scope of the institution.<ref name=Fighting>{{cite news|last=Siegrist|first=Nikki|title=Tech Traditions: Fighting for Change|work=[[The Daily Toreador]]|date=2003-03-03|url=http://media.www.dailytoreador.com/media/storage/paper870/news/2003/03/03/CampusNews/Tech-Traditionsfighting.For.Change-1276134.shtml|accessdate=2008-08-09}}</ref> While most students supported this change, the Board of Directors and many alumni, wanting to preserve the [[Double T]], opposed it.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us: History|publisher=Texas Tech Alumni Association|url=http://www.texastechalumni.org/olc/pub/TTAA/cpages/about_us/history.jsp|accessdate=2008-08-10}}</ref> Other namesâUniversity of the Southwest, Texas Technological College and State University,<ref>{{cite news|last=Hensley|first=Doug|title=Triumph, tragedy in world's spotlight|work=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]|url=http://www.lubbockcentennial.com/Section/1959_1983/3_Hensley.shtml|accessdate=2008-08-10}}</ref> and The Texas University of Art, Science and Technologyâwere considered,<ref name=Game>{{cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20020123163409/redraiders.com/techs75th/namechange.htm|title=Tech began playing name-change game in '50s|accessdate=2008-08-10|work=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]|author=Elizabeth Langton}}</ref> but the Board of Directors chose Texas Tech University, submitting it to the state legislature in 1964. A failed move by [[John Connally|Governor John Connally]] to have the school placed into the [[Texas A&M University System]], as well as continued disagreement and heated debate regarding the school's new name, kept the name change from being approved.<ref name=Controversy /><ref name=Fighting /> In spite of objections by many students and faculty, the Board of Directors again submitted the change in 1969. It finally received the legislature's approval on June 6 and the name Texas Tech University went into effect that September.<ref name=Game /> All of the institution's schools, except Law, became colleges.<ref name=Handbook /><ref>{{cite web|title=General Information|publisher=Texas Tech University Office of Official Publications|url=http://www.depts.ttu.edu/officialpublications/facultyHB/general.php|accessdate=2008-08-12}}</ref>
Line 130: Line 130:
{{-}}
{{-}}
â
== Student life at this college is the best ever ==
+
== Student life ==
[[File:TTUband.jpg|left|thumb|Goin' Band from Raiderland]]
[[File:TTUband.jpg|left|thumb|Goin' Band from Raiderland]]
There are over 390 student clubs and organizations at Texas Tech.<ref>{{cite web|title=Student Organizations|publisher=Texas Tech University Center for Student Life|year=2007|url=http://www.depts.ttu.edu/centerforcampuslife/|accessdate=2007-03-24}}</ref> Many students participate in [[Fraternities and sororities|Greek Life]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Student Organizations: Greek Life|publisher=Texas Tech University Student Affairs|url=http://www.depts.ttu.edu/centerforcampuslife/GreekLife/default.aspx|accessdate=2007-03-24}}</ref> The Student Union Building, located centrally on campus, is the hub of daily student activity. It houses restaurants, coffee shops, a book store, meeting rooms, lecture halls, movie rooms, and study areas as well as the offices and meeting rooms of several student organizations and the Student Government Association. Directly adjacent to the Student Union Building is the School of Music, home of the Texas Tech [[Texas Tech University Goin' Band from Raiderland|Goin' Band from Raiderland]]. The 450-member band, which was awarded the [[Sudler Trophy]] in 1999, performs at all home football games and at various other events.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Sudler Trophy| publisher=[[John Philip Sousa Foundation]]|month=November | year=2007|url=http://www.sousafoundation.org/allProjects/trophy.htm|accessdate=2008-08-14}}</ref>
There are over 390 student clubs and organizations at Texas Tech.<ref>{{cite web|title=Student Organizations|publisher=Texas Tech University Center for Student Life|year=2007|url=http://www.depts.ttu.edu/centerforcampuslife/|accessdate=2007-03-24}}</ref> Many students participate in [[Fraternities and sororities|Greek Life]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Student Organizations: Greek Life|publisher=Texas Tech University Student Affairs|url=http://www.depts.ttu.edu/centerforcampuslife/GreekLife/default.aspx|accessdate=2007-03-24}}</ref> The Student Union Building, located centrally on campus, is the hub of daily student activity. It houses restaurants, coffee shops, a book store, meeting rooms, lecture halls, movie rooms, and study areas as well as the offices and meeting rooms of several student organizations and the Student Government Association. Directly adjacent to the Student Union Building is the School of Music, home of the Texas Tech [[Texas Tech University Goin' Band from Raiderland|Goin' Band from Raiderland]]. The 450-member band, which was awarded the [[Sudler Trophy]] in 1999, performs at all home football games and at various other events.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Sudler Trophy| publisher=[[John Philip Sousa Foundation]]|month=November | year=2007|url=http://www.sousafoundation.org/allProjects/trophy.htm|accessdate=2008-08-14}}</ref>
Line 144: Line 144:
==Athletics==
==Athletics==
{{main|Texas Tech Red Raiders}}
{{main|Texas Tech Red Raiders}}
â
{{seealso|Texas Tech Lady Raiders basketball Texas Tech school for the extremely cool|Texas Tech Red Raiders baseball|Texas Tech Red Raiders men's basketball|Texas Tech Red Raiders football}}
+
{{seealso|Texas Tech Lady Raiders basketball|Texas Tech Red Raiders baseball|Texas Tech Red Raiders men's basketball|Texas Tech Red Raiders football}}
Texas Tech's athletic teams are known as the Red Raiders with the exception of the women's basketball team, which is known as the Lady Raiders. Texas Tech competes in [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I|Division I FBS]] (formerly Division I-A) and is a member of the South Division of the [[Big 12 Conference]]. From 1932 until 1956, the university belonged to the [[Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association]]. After being rejected eight times over a period of more than twenty years, Texas Tech was admitted to the [[Southwest Conference]] on May 12, 1956.<ref>{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Don|title=Texas Tech Turns 75: Tech travels long, winding road of success to Big 12|work=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]|year=1998|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20080102015523/http://www.redraiders.com/techs75th/athletics.htm|accessdate=2008-08-22}}</ref> When the Southwest Conference disbanded in 1995, Texas Tech, along with the [[University of Texas at Austin]], [[Texas A&M University]], and [[Baylor University]], merged with schools from the former [[Big Eight Conference]] to form the Big 12.<ref name="NationalChamps.net">{{cite web|title=Texas Tech Football History Database|publisher=NationalChamps.net|url=http://www.nationalchamps.net/NCAA/database/texastech_database.htm|accessdate=2008-08-14}}</ref>
Texas Tech's athletic teams are known as the Red Raiders with the exception of the women's basketball team, which is known as the Lady Raiders. Texas Tech competes in [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I|Division I FBS]] (formerly Division I-A) and is a member of the South Division of the [[Big 12 Conference]]. From 1932 until 1956, the university belonged to the [[Border Intercollegiate Athletic Association]]. After being rejected eight times over a period of more than twenty years, Texas Tech was admitted to the [[Southwest Conference]] on May 12, 1956.<ref>{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Don|title=Texas Tech Turns 75: Tech travels long, winding road of success to Big 12|work=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]|year=1998|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20080102015523/http://www.redraiders.com/techs75th/athletics.htm|accessdate=2008-08-22}}</ref> When the Southwest Conference disbanded in 1995, Texas Tech, along with the [[University of Texas at Austin]], [[Texas A&M University]], and [[Baylor University]], merged with schools from the former [[Big Eight Conference]] to form the Big 12.<ref name="NationalChamps.net">{{cite web|title=Texas Tech Football History Database|publisher=NationalChamps.net|url=http://www.nationalchamps.net/NCAA/database/texastech_database.htm|accessdate=2008-08-14}}</ref>
Line 163: Line 163:
=== Mascots ===
=== Mascots ===
â
[[The Masked Rider]] is Texas Tech University's oldest mascot and is one of the best ever and completelt tramples the Texas Longhorns. The tradition began in 1936, when "ghost riders" were dared to circle the field prior to home football games. The Masked Rider became an official mascot in 1954, when Joe Kirk Fulton led the team onto the field at the [[Gator Bowl]]. According to reports from those present at the game, the crowd sat in stunned silence as they watched Fulton and his horse Blackie rush onto the football field, followed by the team. After a few moments, the silent crowd burst into cheers. Ed Danforth, a writer for the ''[[Atlanta Journal]]'' who witnessed the event, later wrote, "No team in any bowl game ever made a more sensational entrance."<ref>{{cite news|last=Smits|first=Garry|title=Mascots unmasked: A lasting tradition for Texas Tech began at 1954 Gator Bowl|work=[[The Florida Times-Union]]|date=2007-12-26|url=http://www.jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/122507/col_228878061.shtml|accessdate=2006-04-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ritz|first=Jennifer|title=History of Masked Rider: A history of one of Texas Tech's Oldest and Best-Loved Traditions|work=Texas Techsan Magazine|url=http://www.depts.ttu.edu/spiritsquads/MR_History.htm|accessdate=2008-08-12}}</ref> In 2000, The Masked Rider tradition was commemorated with the unveiling of a statue outside of the university's Frazier Alumni Pavilion. The sculpture, created by artist Grant Speed, is 25 percent larger than life.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wolfe|first=Angel|title=Rider stands larger than life: A new statue dedicated to the history of the Masked Rider finds its home|date=2000-09-11|url=http://media.www.dailytoreador.com/media/storage/paper870/news/2000/09/11/CampusNews/Rider.Stands.Larger.Than.Life-1270800.shtml|accessdate=2008-09-01}}</ref>
+
[[The Masked Rider]] is Texas Tech University's oldest mascot. The tradition began in 1936, when "ghost riders" were dared to circle the field prior to home football games. The Masked Rider became an official mascot in 1954, when Joe Kirk Fulton led the team onto the field at the [[Gator Bowl]]. According to reports from those present at the game, the crowd sat in stunned silence as they watched Fulton and his horse Blackie rush onto the football field, followed by the team. After a few moments, the silent crowd burst into cheers. Ed Danforth, a writer for the ''[[Atlanta Journal]]'' who witnessed the event, later wrote, "No team in any bowl game ever made a more sensational entrance."<ref>{{cite news|last=Smits|first=Garry|title=Mascots unmasked: A lasting tradition for Texas Tech began at 1954 Gator Bowl|work=[[The Florida Times-Union]]|date=2007-12-26|url=http://www.jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/122507/col_228878061.shtml|accessdate=2006-04-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ritz|first=Jennifer|title=History of Masked Rider: A history of one of Texas Tech's Oldest and Best-Loved Traditions|work=Texas Techsan Magazine|url=http://www.depts.ttu.edu/spiritsquads/MR_History.htm|accessdate=2008-08-12}}</ref> In 2000, The Masked Rider tradition was commemorated with the unveiling of a statue outside of the university's Frazier Alumni Pavilion. The sculpture, created by artist Grant Speed, is 25 percent larger than life.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wolfe|first=Angel|title=Rider stands larger than life: A new statue dedicated to the history of the Masked Rider finds its home|date=2000-09-11|url=http://media.www.dailytoreador.com/media/storage/paper870/news/2000/09/11/CampusNews/Rider.Stands.Larger.Than.Life-1270800.shtml|accessdate=2008-09-01}}</ref>
[[File:MRlogo.png|left|thumb|The Masked Rider logo]]
[[File:MRlogo.png|left|thumb|The Masked Rider logo]]
Today the Masked Rider, with [[guns up]], leads the team onto the field for all home games. This mascot, adorned in a distinctive [[gaucho]] hat like the ones worn by members of the marching band, is one of the most visible figures at Texas Tech. Brianne Aucutt-Hight, a senior animal science major from [[Clovis, New Mexico]], will represent the university as the Masked Rider during 2009/10.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Tech Masked Rider from Clovis|work=[[Clovis News Journal]]|date=2009-04-20|url=http://www.cnjonline.com/news/tech_33398___article.html/new_clovis.html|accessdate=2009-04-23}}</ref>
Today the Masked Rider, with [[guns up]], leads the team onto the field for all home games. This mascot, adorned in a distinctive [[gaucho]] hat like the ones worn by members of the marching band, is one of the most visible figures at Texas Tech. Brianne Aucutt-Hight, a senior animal science major from [[Clovis, New Mexico]], will represent the university as the Masked Rider during 2009/10.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Tech Masked Rider from Clovis|work=[[Clovis News Journal]]|date=2009-04-20|url=http://www.cnjonline.com/news/tech_33398___article.html/new_clovis.html|accessdate=2009-04-23}}</ref>
